questions.text: What is the initial treatment of choice for chronic gout in a 52-year-old woman with hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, severe pain, and swelling in her left great toe, sporadic similar episodes over the past 3 years, and a daily intake of 6 beers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • Allopurinol: Allopurinol is the first choice for chronic gout. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces the production of uric acid and helps prevent the formation of urate crystals that cause gout attacks.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is another xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the management of chronic gout. While it is effective, it is not the first choice in this scenario.

Option C. Probenecid: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that increases the excretion of uric acid from the body. It is often used as an adjunctive therapy in patients with gout who do not achieve adequate control with xanthine oxidase inhibitors. However, it is not the first choice for initial treatment.

Option D. Sulfinpyrazone: Sulfinpyrazone is also a uricosuric agent used in the management of gout. Similar to Probenecid, it is not the first choice for initial treatment.

questions.text: Drug for HIV induced lipodystrophy:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tesamorelin:

  • Tesamorelin is a synthetic growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) analog that is used specifically for reducing abdominal fat in patients with HIV-associated lipodystrophy. It works by stimulating the release of growth hormone, which helps to reduce visceral fat accumulation. It is the primary medication approved for this indication.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Somatropin:

  • Somatropin is a recombinant growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiencies and growth disorders. It is not specifically indicated for HIV-induced lipodystrophy, although it may have some effect on body composition. Its use is more general and not targeted at HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

Option C - Octreotide:

  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analog used to treat conditions like acromegaly and certain types of tumors. It is not used for treating HIV-induced lipodystrophy. Its effects are related to inhibiting growth hormone release rather than addressing fat distribution issues related to HIV.

Option D - Pegvisomant:

  • Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly by blocking the action of growth hormone at its receptor. It is not used for treating HIV-induced lipodystrophy, as its mechanism does not target fat redistribution or accumulation associated with HIV.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout?

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID

choices.text: Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAIDC & D

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - A, B & C:

  • Aspirin is generally avoided in the treatment of gout because it can interfere with uric acid excretion, potentially exacerbating the condition.
  • It competes with uric acid for renal secretion, reducing uric acid elimination and increasing the risk of accumulation.
  • The DOC in acute attack of gout:
    • First-line: NSAIDs (all except aspirin and paracetamol)
      • E.g. Naproxen, piroxicam, diclofenac, indomethacin, or etoricoxib
    • NSAID resistant cases: Colchicine
    • Colchicine resistant cases: Intra-articular corticosteroids

Diclofenac is an NSAID used to treat acute gout attacks. It tends to accumulate in inflamed joints, offering targeted relief from pain and inflammation.

Indomethacin is another NSAID frequently used to manage gout. It works by inhibiting the production of inflammatory substances like prostaglandins, helping to alleviate pain and inflammation associated with gout.

Drugs precipitating Gout:

  • Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
  • Aspirin (Low dose)
  • Niacin
  • Thiazide & Lasix
  • Ethambutol
  • Alcohol
  • Pyrazinamide

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the management of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chronic gout

Explanation:

  • Pegloticase is used in the management of Chronic gout.
  • It is specifically indicated for patients with severe gout who have not responded well to other treatments or who cannot tolerate other treatment options.

MOA: Metabolizes uric acid ,converts it into allantoin and excreted in urine, which helps to reduce the build-up of uric acid crystals in the joints and alleviate symptoms of gout

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine

  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) is not an indicated use for pegloticase. Rheumatoid arthritis is a different autoimmune condition that requires different treatment approaches using NSAIDs and DMARDs

Psoriatic arthritis (Option C) is also not an indicated use for pegloticase. Psoriatic arthritis is a type of arthritis associated with psoriasis and requires specific treatments targeting both joint inflammation and skin manifestation.

Paralytic ileus (Option D) is a condition characterised by the impairment of intestinal motility, and pegloticase is not indicated for its treatment. Paralytic ileus usually requires supportive care and addressing the underlying cause of the condition.

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to reduce the frequency of future headache episodes in a 26-year-old female patient who experiences one-sided pulsating headaches accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and finds relief in a dimly lit environment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Propranolol

Explanation:

  • The clinical history indicates a migraine headache. Propranolol is commonly used for migraine prophylaxis, with effects typically observed within 4 weeks and sustained with prolonged therapy.

Use of propranolol

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

 

Acute management of migraine attack

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

Prophylaxis of migraine

  • Propranolol (Beta-blocker, DOC for migraine prophylaxis).
  • Flunarizine (Calcium channel blocker)
  • Cyproheptadine: (Antihistamine that can help alleviate migraine symptoms).
  • Candesartan: (Angiotensin II receptor blocker).
  • Clonidine
  • Pizotifen (Serotonin antagonist that can help reduce migraine frequency).
  • Gabapentin, valproate, nortriptyline, and topiramate are medications that can help manage migraine symptoms by releasing the neurotransmitter GABA.
  • Topiramate
  • Methysergide (Manages migraine symptoms by blocking serotonin receptors).

Alprazolam (Option B) and Diazepam (Option C) are benzodiazepines that can be used in acute attacks of migraine by inducing sleep in the patient.

Fluoxetine (Option D) is an SSRI that may help treat migraine in some people.

questions.text: A patient took a drug for migraine treatment, following which there was numbness, and his hand appeared as below. What is the possible drug that was taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Dihydroergotamine

Explanation:

  • The patient's numbness and hand discolouration, as shown in the image, suggest treatment with dihydroergotamine for migraine.

Dihydroergotamine

Drug class

Ergot alkaloids

MOA

Partial agonist activity at 5HT1B/1D receptors causes vasoconstriction, reducing migraine-associated inflammation.

Uses

Acute migraine attack

Side effects

  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
    • Manifest as numbness, tingling, and discolouration of the fingers, commonly referred to as Raynaud's phenomenon.
    • Discolouration of fingers - White → Blue→ Red
    • It can lead to gangrene of extremities and organs with end arteries.
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Paradoxical headache and dizziness
  • Flushing
  • Nasal congestion
  • Chest pain
  • Muscle pain

Sumatriptan (Option B) is a medication used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. While it can cause side effects such as tingling or numbness, it is not associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon, unlike Dihydroergotamine.

Butorphanol (Option C) is an opioid analgesic used for the treatment of pain, including migraines. It is not typically associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Aspirin (Option D) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used for pain relief. It is not known to cause peripheral vasoconstriction or Raynaud's phenomenon.

questions.text: What is Zileuton's mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 5-Lipooxygenase inhibitor

Explanation:

  • Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, which is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes.
  • It is primarily used to maintain asthma and is particularly effective in reducing bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation in conditions like asthma.

Cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors (Option A), such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), work by inhibiting the activity of the COX enzymes involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes. Zileuton does not inhibit cyclooxygenase.

5-phosphodiesterase inhibitors (Option C) inhibit the enzyme that breaks down cyclic nucleotides like cAMP and cGMP. Drugs like sildenafil are used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Zileuton does not inhibit 5-phosphodiesterase.

Prevention of mast cell degranulation (Option D) is seen with mast cell stabilisers, like cromolyn sodium. Mast cell degranulation refers to the release of inflammatory mediators, such as histamine and cytokines, from mast cells. Zileuton does not directly prevent mast cell degranulation.

questions.text: Which of the following DMARD uses require regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydroxychloroquine

Explanation:

The use of Hydroxychloroquine requires regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination due to the risk of Ocular toxicity, such as

  • Vortex keratopathy (cornea verticallata)
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract
  • Bull’s eye retinopathy (deposits like concentric rings in the retina)

 

Hydroxychloroquine

MAO

Hydroxychloroquine⟶ Lysosome Accumulation ⟶ ↑ Lysosomal pH ⟶ Inhibits Antigen Processing ⟶ ↓ Antigen-MHC Presentation ⟶ ↓ T-Cell Activation ⟶ Inhibits TLRs ⟶ ↓ Pro-inflammatory Cytokines ⟶ ↓ Inflammation in RA

Uses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Prevention and treatment of malaria
  • Autoimmune diseases like Sjögren's syndrome

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Dermatological (rash, pigmentation changes)
  • Ocular toxicity:
    • Vortex keratopathy (cornea verticallata)
    • Posterior subcapsular cataract
    • Bull’s eye retinopathy (deposits like concentric rings in the retina)
  • Cardiovascular (cardiomyopathy, QT prolongation)
  • Neurological (headache, dizziness)
  • Hematologic (anaemia, leukopenia)

Note
  • Regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for retinal toxicity.
  • The maximum safe dose of hydroxychloroquine to minimise the risk of bull's-eye maculopathy is recommended to be 5 mg/kg of real body weight per day.

 

Methotrexate (Option A) does not cause ocular toxicity but requires regular monitoring of liver function tests (LFTs), complete blood counts (CBC), and renal function. It can cause hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression, and pulmonary fibrosis.

Sulfasalazine (Option C) requires regular monitoring of CBC (to detect hemolytic anaemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia) and LFTs (for hepatotoxicity).

Leflunomide (Option D) requires regular monitoring of LFTs because of the risk of severe hepatotoxicity. It also necessitates monitoring for hypertension and teratogenicity in women of childbearing age.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of allopurinol is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Xanthine oxidase inhibition:

  • Allopurinol is a medication primarily used for the management of gout and certain types of kidney stones.

Mechanism of Action

  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. It inhibits the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and then to uric acid.

  • By inhibiting xanthine oxidase, allopurinol reduces the production of uric acid, thereby lowering the uric acid levels in the blood and urine.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Recombinant uricase: Recombinant uricase, also known as pegloticase, is a medication used for the treatment of chronic gout in adults who have not responded adequately to other therapies. Uricase catalyzes the conversion of uric acid, a byproduct of purine metabolism, into allantoin, a compound that is more soluble and can be easily eliminated by the kidneys. By converting uric acid to allantoin, pegloticase reduces the serum uric acid levels and helps dissolve urate crystals in tissues.

Option C - Increase uric acid excretion: Uricosuric agents work by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubules, thereby increasing its elimination in the urine. Eg Probenecid, Benzbromarone and Lesinurad.

Option D - Decrease chemotaxis : Colchicine inhibits granulocyte migration and is used in acute gout.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for the prophylaxis of migraine?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C. Flutamide

  • Flutamide is not used for the prophylaxis of migraine. Flutamide is an antiandrogen medication primarily used in the treatment of certain hormone-dependent conditions, such as prostate cancer and hirsutism. It is not indicated or commonly prescribed for the prevention or prophylaxis of migraine headaches.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be effective in reducing the frequency and severity of migraines. It works by blocking the action of adrenaline and other stress hormones, which can trigger migraines.

Option B: Imipramine: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that is sometimes used for migraine prophylaxis. It helps regulate the levels of certain neurotransmitters in the brain, which may help prevent migraine attacks.

Option D: Flunarizine: Flunarizine is a calcium channel blocker that has been used in some countries for the prophylaxis of migraines. It works by reducing the influx of calcium into cells, which can help prevent the excessive dilation of blood vessels in the brain that is associated with migraines.

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanisms of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 5-HT agonist

  • 5-HT agonists, such as triptans, are commonly prescribed for migraine treatment. These drugs stimulate 5-HT receptors, leading to vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels. However, in patients with a history of angina/MI, they may also cause vasoconstriction in coronary arteries, potentially triggering chest pain or even a myocardial infarction due to reduced blood flow to the heart.

Migraine

Pathophysiology

  • Migraine is characterized by a pulsating unilateral headache that comes in bouts lasting 4-48 hours and is associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, and vertigo.
  • 5th cranial nerve stimulation (5-HT1F receptor) → Release of neurotransmitters like CGRP, neurokinin, Nitrous Oxide, 5-HT → Dilation of meningeal vessels causing headache

Drugs used in acute migraine

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

5-HT antagonists (Option A) block serotonin’s effects and are generally not linked to chest pain in patients with angina/MI. While they may have other side effects, they are not typically associated with chest pain in this context.

Calcium Channel Blocker action (Option C) are used to treat angina and hypertension by causing vasodilation. They are not typically associated with chest pain in patients with angina/MI.

Nitric oxide-mediated vasodilation (Option D) promotes blood vessel relaxation and is used in conditions like angina. It is not commonly linked to causing chest pain in patients with a history of angina/MI.

questions.text: What is the most suitable medication for alleviating the symptoms of a 56-year-old postmenopausal woman who has been experiencing worsening pain and swelling in her left knee for the past 6 months? questions.solution:

Incorrect options:

questions.text: Why is cisatracurium preferred over atracurium?

choices.text: It has rapid onset of action
It has less depressant action on heart
It has short duration of action
It causes less release of histamine

questions.solution:
Correct Option is d. It causes less release of histamine.

Option D. It causes less release of histamine: Cisatracurium is preferred over atracurium because it causes less release of histamine. Histamine release can lead to adverse effects such as bronchoconstriction, hypotension, and flushing. Cisatracurium is considered a non-histamine-releasing neuromuscular blocking agent, making it a favorable choice in patients who are susceptible to histamine-related reactions.

Incorrect Options

Option A. It has rapid onset of action: Cisatracurium and atracurium have similar onset of action. Both drugs are classified as intermediate-acting neuromuscular blocking agents and have comparable time to onset.

Option B. It has less depressant action on the heart: Cisatracurium and atracurium have similar cardiovascular effects. They do not have significant direct effects on the heart and do not cause substantial cardiovascular depression.

Option C. It has a short duration of action: Cisatracurium and atracurium have similar durations of action. The duration of effect for both drugs is moderate, allowing for adequate muscle relaxation during surgical procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PGE1:

  • PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1) helps in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus. It acts as a vasodilator and keeps the ductus arteriosus open, allowing blood to bypass the lungs in fetal circulation. PGE1 is naturally produced in the body and is commonly used as a medication (e.g., alprostadil) to maintain ductal patency in certain congenital heart defects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - PGF2α : PGF2α (Prostaglandin F2α) is not involved in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus. Instead, it plays a role in vasoconstriction and contraction of smooth muscle.

Option C - PGH2: PGH2 (Prostaglandin H2) is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of other prostaglandins and is not directly involved in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

Option D - PGI2: While PGI2 (Prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation, it does not specifically play a role in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: How does colchicine work in the body?

choices.text: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colchicine:

  • Colchicine exerts its mechanism of action by binding to tubulin and inhibiting granulocyte migration, specifically targeting the microtubules.
  • This action reduces the inflammatory response associated with conditions such as gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhibits synthesis of uric acid: This is not the mechanism of action of colchicine. Colchicine does not directly inhibit the synthesis of uric acid.

Option B - Promotes excretion of uric acid: Colchicine does not promote the excretion of uric acid. Its primary action is related to its anti-inflammatory properties.

Option C - Inhibits xanthine oxidase enzyme: Colchicine does not inhibit the xanthine oxidase enzyme. Xanthine oxidase inhibitors, such as allopurinol, are used to reduce uric acid production.

questions.text: Which of the following is the compound that prostaglandin, indicated for multiple conditions, is derived from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Prostaglandins are a class of lipid compounds that play diverse roles in the body, including regulating inflammation, blood flow, and various physiological processes. They are derived from a fatty acid called arachidonic acid, which is an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid.
  • Arachidonic acid is obtained from the diet and is also synthesized in the body from essential fatty acids. When the body needs prostaglandins, arachidonic acid is metabolized by enzymes called cyclooxygenases (COX) to produce prostaglandins.
  • These prostaglandins then act as local hormones, exerting their effects in the immediate vicinity of their synthesis. They are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including inflammation, pain signaling, blood vessel constriction and dilation, regulation of blood clotting, and control of gastrointestinal secretions.

Incorrect Option:

Option A) Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid found in various foods, including animal fats and chocolate. It is not directly involved in the synthesis of prostaglandins.

Option C) Linoleic acid: Linoleic acid is an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid that is also involved in the synthesis of various lipid compounds in the body. However, it is not the direct precursor of prostaglandins.

Option D) Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is an omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid, and while it is involved in the synthesis of other important lipid compounds in the body, it is not the precursor for prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paracetamol

 

Explanation:

  • NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine) is a toxic metabolite that is formed when paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen) is metabolized by the liver.
  • Under normal circumstances, paracetamol is metabolized into non-toxic compounds that are excreted in the urine.
  • However, when the dose of paracetamol exceeds a certain threshold, the liver's metabolic pathways become overwhelmed, and NAPQI accumulates in the liver, where it can cause hepatotoxicity.
  • Acetaminophen nomogram is used to interpret serum acetaminophen concentrations in relation to time since ingestion in order to assess potential hepatotoxicity.
  • Paracetamol overdose → Increased production of toxic metabolite NAPQI (catalysed by CYP2E1) → Depletes glutathione (which normally neutralises NAPQI) → Leads to NAPQI binding to liver cells, causing Zonal necrosis/ centrilobular necrosis with periportal sparing.

 

Aspirin (Option A), Diclofenac (Option C) ,and Ketorolac (Option D are not metabolized to NAPQI.

questions.text: Methotrexate usage causes reduced synthesis of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - TMP (Thymidine Monophosphate):

  • Methotrexate is a folate analog that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). DHFR is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a cofactor required for the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis. By inhibiting this enzyme, methotrexate reduces the synthesis of TMP, leading to impaired DNA synthesis, particularly affecting rapidly dividing cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CMP (Cytidine Monophosphate):

  • CMP synthesis is not directly affected by methotrexate. Cytidine monophosphate is derived from the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway, which is not directly influenced by the folate cycle inhibited by methotrexate.

Option C - GMP (Guanosine Monophosphate):

  • GMP synthesis is part of the purine biosynthesis pathway. While folate metabolism plays a role in purine synthesis, methotrexate's primary effect is on the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, particularly affecting TMP synthesis.

Option D - AMP (Adenosine Monophosphate):

  • Similar to GMP, AMP is a purine nucleotide. While methotrexate can indirectly affect purine synthesis due to folate pathway inhibition, the most direct and significant impact is on TMP synthesis in the pyrimidine pathway.

questions.text: In the management of Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome, which of the following drugs is the least useful?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - NSAID Analgesic:

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a class of medications commonly used to relieve pain and reduce inflammation. However, they are generally not considered as first-line treatment for neuropathic pain syndromes like Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome. Neuropathic pain is often not primarily driven by inflammation, and NSAIDs are less effective in addressing the underlying mechanisms of neuropathic pain. Therefore, among the options provided, NSAID analgesics are the least useful in managing Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pregabalin: Pregabalin is an anticonvulsant and analgesic medication commonly used to treat neuropathic pain conditions, including Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome. It acts by modulating calcium channels in the nervous system, reducing the release of neurotransmitters involved in pain signaling. Pregabalin can be effective in managing neuropathic pain, including the pain associated with thalamic lesions. Therefore, pregabalin is considered useful in Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome.

Option B - Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant medication often used to treat various types of neuropathic pain, including trigeminal neuralgia and diabetic neuropathy. It works by stabilizing sodium channels in neurons, reducing their excitability. Carbamazepine has been shown to provide pain relief in some patients with Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome, making it a useful option in managing the condition.

Option C - Gabapentin: Gabapentin is another anticonvulsant medication commonly used for neuropathic pain management. It modulates calcium channels and is believed to inhibit the release of certain neurotransmitters involved in pain transmission. Similar to pregabalin, gabapentin has been found to be effective in treating neuropathic pain conditions, including Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome. Therefore, gabapentin can be considered useful in managing this condition.

questions.text: A female delivered a male baby developed PPH was treated with ergometrine but not able to stop the bleeding. Which of the following is a prostaglandin derivative that can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Carboprost:

  • Carboprost tromethamine is a prostaglandin F2α analogue that is often used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage that has not responded to other interventions, such as uterine massage, oxytocin, and ergometrine. It causes uterine contractions and helps to control bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue. While it can be used to prevent and treat postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), it is not the first-line option in cases of severe PPH that do not respond to other interventions.

Option B - Dinoprost: Dinoprost, also known as prostaglandin F2α, is used for various medical purposes, including induction of labor and abortion, but it is not the primary choice for treating PPH.

Option D - Latanoprost: Latanoprost is not used to treat postpartum hemorrhage. It is an eye drop medication used to treat certain types of glaucoma and ocular hypertension by reducing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with complaints of urine hesitancy and retention of urine comes to ER. On investigation, his USG shows residual urine of 130 ml. Which of the following drug is used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5 alpha reductase inhibitors:

  • 5 alpha reductase inhibitors are commonly used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is a condition characterized by an enlarged prostate gland causing symptoms such as urine hesitancy, retention, frequent urination, etc. These medications work by reducing the size of the prostate gland, relieving the pressure on the urethra, and improving urinary flow.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are commonly used to treat conditions such as high blood pressure, angina, and certain heart rhythm disorders. They do not directly impact urine hesitancy or retention and are not the appropriate treatment for this patient's condition.

Option C - ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are primarily used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. They do not have a direct role in treating urine hesitancy or retention caused by an enlarged prostate.

Option D - Aldosterone antagonist: Aldosterone antagonists are typically used to treat conditions like heart failure, high blood pressure, and certain kidney diseases by affecting the balance of electrolytes and fluid in the body. They are not indicated for the treatment of urine hesitancy or retention caused by an enlarged prostate.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma patients during the management of postpartum haemorrhage is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Carboprost

Carboprost is contraindicated in women with asthma when treating postpartum hemorrhage.

  • A derivative of prostaglandin F2α and the correct dosage for managing PPH is 250 μg IM, repeated every 15-90 minutes, up to 8 doses.
  • Side effects: Diarrhea, hypertension, vomiting, fever, flushing, tachycardia
  • Contraindications: asthma, pulmonary hypertension, suspected amniotic fluid embolism, and certain renal, liver, and cardiac conditions.

Oxytocin (Option B) is a hormone secreted by the posterior pituitary alongside arginine vasopressin. It is the drug of choice for managing postpartum hemorrhage.

Dinoprostone (Option C) is a prostaglandin E2 analogue (PGE2) and the drug of choice for cervical ripening (vaginal use). It is also utilized for labour induction and medical abortion.

Methyl ergometrine (Option D) is an ergot alkaloid that acts on the myometrium, inducing strong and frequent uterine contractions, which lead to uterine spasms. It is used in the management of postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A physician prescribed a drug that reduces the synthesis of uric acid for the gout. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (XO).
  • Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting XO, the enzyme that converts xanthine to uric acid.
  • Allopurinol competitively inhibits XO at low concentrations and is a non-competitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It is the drug of choice for the treatment of chronic gout.
  • Other uses of allopurinol:
    • Tumour lysis syndrome
    • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
    • Post-transplant patients

Probenecid (Option A) is a uricosuric agent that acts by increasing uric acid’s excretion in the urine.

Colchicine (Option B) is an anti-inflammatory medication commonly used to treat acute gout attacks but doesn’t affect uric acid levels.

Diclofenac (Option C) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can also be used to manage gout symptoms but does not inhibit uric acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which among the following is not preferred as an analgesic in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ketorolac:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by joint inflammation and pain. The goal of treatment in rheumatoid arthritis is to reduce pain, inflammation, and joint damage. Analgesics are medications that are used to relieve pain.

  • Ketorolac is also an NSAID, but it is not preferred for use in rheumatoid arthritis due to its potential side effects. It is a potent analgesic that works by blocking the production of prostaglandins. However, it is associated with a higher risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, kidney damage, and other serious adverse effects. Ketorolac is typically used for short-term pain relief in conditions such as postoperative pain, renal colic, and migraines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tramadol: Tramadol is an opioid analgesic commonly used to manage pain in rheumatoid arthritis. It has both opioid and non-opioid mechanisms of action and is considered effective for moderate to severe pain. 

Option C - Naproxen: Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used to manage pain and inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis. It works by blocking the production of prostaglandins, which are responsible for pain and inflammation. However, long-term use of NSAIDs may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, cardiovascular events, and kidney damage.

Option D - Oxycodone: Oxycodone is another opioid analgesic sometimes used to manage pain in rheumatoid arthritis. It is more potent than tramadol and may be used for severe pain. However, tramadol may cause side effects such as nausea, dizziness, and constipation.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent a nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acetaminophen

Explanation:

  • As this patient has recently undergone nephrectomy due to chronic kidney disease, Acetaminophen is the most appropriate postoperative analgesic.
  • It inhibits COX-3, increases endogenous cannabinoids, and stimulates TRP-V1 receptors, resulting in analgesia and antipyretic properties.
  • It is generally considered safe and well-tolerated in patients with chronic kidney disease.
  • Patients with chronic kidney disease often have reduced kidney function and impaired clearance of certain medications, including NSAIDs and NSAIDs, which can cause further kidney damage and potentially worsen renal function, so their use is generally avoided in this patient population.
  • NSAIDs cause impairment of prostaglandin-induced inhibition of chlorine reabsorption and ADH action, which results in salt and water retention. It also inhibits COX-2-derived prostaglandins, which regulate renal medullary blood flow, resulting in elevated blood pressure and increased risk of cardiac failure.

However, acetaminophen is considered a safer alternative as it is primarily metabolized in the liver and excreted by the kidneys in a non-toxic form.

 

Naproxen (Option A), Indomethacin (Option B), and Diclofenac (Option C), are NSAIDs that are not safe to be used in CKD.

questions.text: Urine alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspirin

 

Explanation:

  • Urinary alkalinization is a technique used to increase the pH of urine, which can increase the excretion of weakly acidic drugs that are cleared by the kidneys such as aspirin.

Urine alkalinization involves administering bicarbonate (usually sodium bicarbonate) to make the urine more basic.

  • This raises the pH of the urine, causing acidic drugs like aspirin to become more ionized and thus increase renal excretion.

Aspirin Toxicity:

Explanation
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in metabolic acidosis (Compensatory metabolic acidosis). High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis

Dosage and Toxicity
  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism)
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation
  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management

Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

 

 

Beta-blockers (Option A): The primary treatment for beta-blocker toxicity includes the use of atropine, glucagon, and sometimes calcium to improve heart rate and contractility. Urine alkalinization is not a recommended treatment for beta-blocker poisoning.

 

Calcium channel blockers (Option B): CCB toxicity is typically treated with calcium (IV calcium gluconate or calcium chloride) and other interventions like glucagon and insulin therapy. Urine alkalinization is not effective for this type of toxicity.

 

Acetaminophen (Option C): The treatment for acetaminophen toxicity involves N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which replenishes glutathione and helps in detoxifying the harmful NAPQI metabolite. Urine alkalinization is not used for acetaminophen poisoning.

questions.text: What medication is administered to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in a 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma who has experienced these symptoms during her previous treatment visits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Palonosetron

  • Palonosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is highly effective in preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), especially in patients who have experienced these symptoms previously.
  • It is preferred due to its long half-life and efficacy in controlling both acute and delayed nausea and vomiting following chemotherapy.

5HT-3 Antagonists (Anti-motility drugs)

5HT-4 Agonists (Prokinetic drugs)
  • Block 5HT-3 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system.
  • Decrease intestinal motility and secretion.
  • Inhibit the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the area postrema, reducing nausea and vomiting.
  • Activate 5HT-4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Increase gastrointestinal motility and secretion.
  • Enhances the release of acetylcholine from enteric neurons.
  • Ondansetron
  • Granisetron
  • Dolasetron
  • Palonosetron
  • Alosetron
  • Metoclopramide
  • Cisapride (withdrawn due to QT prolongation)
  • Tegaserod (restricted use due to cardiovascular risks)
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
  • Radiation-induced nausea and vomiting (RINV)
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhoea (IBS-D): Alosetron
  • Gastroparesis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Chronic constipation
  • Postoperative ileus
  • Headache
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness
  • Fatigue
  • Prolonged QT interval (rare)
  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Prolonged QT interval (Cisapride, Tegaserod)

Metoclopramide (Option A) is a prokinetic agent that works by increasing gastric motility, but it is not as effective as 5-HT3 antagonists like palonosetron in preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Ropinirole (Option B) is a dopamine agonist used primarily for Parkinson's disease and restless leg syndrome. It is not used to prevent nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy.

Domperidone (Option C) is a dopamine antagonist that can be used to treat nausea and vomiting, but it is generally less effective than 5-HT3 antagonists for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and is not the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of chronic NSAID usage. Physical examination reveals rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Peptic ulcer perforation

  • The patient presenting with diffuse abdominal pain, chronic NSAID usage, and rigidity on examination is highly suggestive of perforation of a peptic ulcer.
  • The most relevant radiological finding in this context would be free air under the diaphragm, visible on an X-ray, which is a hallmark of hollow viscus perforation.
  • Chronic NSAID use increases the risk of developing peptic ulcers, which can perforate and lead to peritonitis, presenting with abdominal rigidity and pain.

Adverse effects of NSAIDs

System

Side effects

Additional information

Gastrointestinal

Nausea and vomiting

Selective COX-2 inhibitors: Less likely to cause GI side effects

GI hemorrhage, erosion, Ulcers

Due to ↓prostaglandin synthesis, leading to loss of mucosal protection

Hematological

Platelet dysfunction → Increased bruising and hemorrhage risk

From reduced thromboxane A2 activity

Renal
  • Renal dysfunction/failure
  • Reduction in efficacy of loop diuretics & antihypertensives
  • Salt and water retention
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Renal papillary necrosis
  • Interstitial nephritis
  • Analgesic nephropathy

Analgesic nephropathy leads to renal failure with papillary necrosis and chronic interstitial nephritis, which is less common since the ban of phenacetin.

 

Cardiovascular

  • Edema

Hepatic
  • Elevated liver enzymes
  • Hepatic failure

Hypersensitivity

 
  • Urticaria
  • Flushing
  • Anaphylaxis

Dermatological
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome
  • Photosensitivity

questions.text: A patient presents with acute swelling in the big toe, and his serum uric acid levels were increased. The doctor prescribed medicine to manage this acute condition. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Neutrophil chemotaxis prevention

  • The clinical scenario describes a case of acute gout, characterised by acute inflammation in the big toe (podagra) and elevated serum uric acid levels.
  • The management of acute gout involves medications that reduce inflammation rather than those targeting uric acid levels.
  • Colchicine is the drug of choice for Acute Gout.
  • Mechanism of Action: Colchicine prevents neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation by disrupting microtubule polymerisation. This reduces the inflammatory response triggered by urate crystals in the joint.

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine  (spindle poison)
  • MOA: Microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

 

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors  (Option C)
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents (Option B)
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the closure of patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Indomethacin

  • Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is commonly used to promote the closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), especially in premature infants.
  • It works by inhibiting prostaglandins, which play a role in keeping the ductus arteriosus open.
  • Ibuprofen, a nonselective COX inhibitor, is the drug of choice for closing a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, primarily PGE2 (maintains ductus arteriosus patency during fetal development) through COX enzyme inhibition.
  • Due to its lower risk of renal toxicity, it is considered a safer option than indomethacin for PDA closure in neonates.

 

Uses of NSAIDs

NSAIDs are avoided in
  • Analgesic (in all types of pain except neuropathic pain)
  • Antipyretic
  • Anti-inflammatory
  • Antiplatelet
  • Tocolytic
  • Closure of PDA
  • Pregnancy (as it causes premature closure of ductus arteriosus)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Safest NSAID in these cases is paracetamol.

Magnesium sulfate (Option A) is used to manage conditions such as preeclampsia, preterm labour, torsades de pointes, acute myocardial infarction, eclampsia, seizure control, and migraines. It does not influence the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

Alprostadil (Option B) is used to treat erectile dysfunction, patent ductus arteriosus, and pulmonary arterial hypertension. It is primarily employed to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus, not to close it.

Paracetamol (Option D) is an analgesic and antipyretic used for pain relief and reducing fever. It does not facilitate the closure of the patent ductus arteriosus, as it does not impact prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: A student complains of developing urticaria following the consumption of seafood. Considering the need for non-sedating medication due to an upcoming exam, which of the following drugs would you choose to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Fexofenadine

  • Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine that is non-sedating and effective for managing allergic reactions like urticaria (hives). It does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly, so it does not cause sedation, making it ideal for the student who needs to stay alert for the exam.
  • Sedation and drowsiness are common side effects of first-generation antihistamines, which can impair cognitive function and alertness, affecting the patient's ability to perform tasks requiring mental acuity throughout the day.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman on ART was prescribed ergotamine for a migraine attack four days ago. She presented with complaints that she has been unable to feel her legs, from the mid-thigh to her toes, for the past two days. The angiographic image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Ergotism

  • Based on the clinical features and CT angiography, which shows diffuse symmetrical luminal narrowing of the lower limb vessel, the patient most likely has ergotism.
  • Ergotism is a condition caused by the ingestion of ergot-contaminated grains or the use of ergot-derived medications such as ergotamine.
  • In patients who are HIV positive and are currently on ART may have Han IV protease inhibitors in their ART regimen, thus resulting in the inhibition of CYP3A4, which is also responsible for the metabolism of ergotamine.
  • This results in the accumulation of toxic levels of ergotamine in the patient, causing ergotism.

Ergotamine

  • Partial agonist and antagonist at alpha-adrenergic, 5HT1 and 5HT2 receptors.
  • Produces sustained vasoconstriction, vasomotor centre depression and visceral smooth muscle contraction
  • Side effects of Ergotamine
    • Coronary vasoconstriction
    • Gangrene of the extremities
    • Hypertension
    • Arrhythmias
    • Sweating
    • Bradycardia
  • Contraindications
    • Ischaemic heart disease
    • Hypertension
    • Epilepsy
    • Hepatic or renal impairment
    • Pregnancy

 

Atherosclerosis (Option A) involves chronic plaque formation leading to arterial narrowing. While ischemia may occur, the acute onset of symptoms in this case is more consistent with drug-induced vasospasm.

Polyradicular Neuropathy (Option C) would present with gradual, symmetric sensory or motor loss, not acute ischemic changes or angiographic findings of vasospasm.

Herniated disc (Option D) typically causes radicular pain and motor weakness, not ischemic limb findings or angiographic evidence of vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. Which of the following effects will the drug have on the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Premature closure of ductus arteriosus

Explanation:

  • Indomethacin is a non-selective COX inhibitor that causes premature closure of ductus arteriosus if used in pregnant women.
  • It is a nonselective COX inhibitor that has anti-inflammatory, antipyretic and analgesic properties.
  • It is an approved treatment for the closure of persistent ductus arteriosus in premature infants and is given intravenously, but if used by a pregnant woman, it can prematurely close the ductus arteriosus, which is essential for fetal circulation and can be fatal to the fetus.

Uses

  • Arthritis: Rheumatoid, Gout and Osteoarthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • It has limited use due to the availability of safer, well-tolerated and effective alternatives.

Adverse effects

  • Frontal headache
  • Dizziness
  • Diarrhoea
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Hepatitis
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia
  • Rarely aplastic anemia

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This occurs due to the inhibition of ________ by aspirin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thromboxane

Explanation:

  • Inhibition of thromboxane by aspirin results in bleeding within the gastrointestinal tract, which leads to the presence of occult blood in the stool.

Aspirin

MOA

Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, particularly COX-1 and COX-2. COX-1 is involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxane.

Effect on platelets

  • Thromboxane A2 is a potent pro-inflammatory and pro-thrombotic molecule that promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
  • By inhibiting COX-1, aspirin reduces the production of thromboxane A2, which leads to decreased platelet aggregation and a reduced tendency for blood clot formation, which can contribute to gastrointestinal bleeding, including the presence of occult blood in the stool.

Uses

  • Analgesic: Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Antipyretic
  • Antiplatelet: Post Myocardial infraction and CVA

Adverse effects

0.5-2 g/day - analgesic dose

  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Epigastric discomfort

3-5 g/day - anti-inflammatory dose

  • Salicylism - vertigo, hyperventilation, tinnitus, reversible loss of hearing
  • Hepatitis
  • Hypersensitivity

Reye’s syndrome: A rare condition seen when salicylates are given in children suffering from viral infections such as influenza, presenting as acute liver failure.

 

Phospholipase A2 (Option A) plays a crucial role in the release of arachidonic acid from cell membrane phospholipids, which is a precursor for prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes. Aspirin does not inhibit PLA2 directly; rather, it acts downstream of this enzyme by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes that convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins and thromboxanes.

Phospholipase C (Option C) is involved in cellular signal transduction, where it cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) into diacylglycerol (DAG) and inositol trisphosphate (IP3). These molecules act as second messengers in pathways regulating calcium signalling and protein kinase C activation.

Phospholipase D (Option D) is involved in lipid signalling pathways. It hydrolyzes phosphatidylcholine to produce phosphatidic acid, a precursor for several signalling molecules.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the outpatient department for a routine health check-up. The patient is obese and has smoked for 30 years. His past medical history includes hypertension for 10 years and diabetes mellitus for 8 years, for which he takes amlodipine and metformin pills regularly. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and lab findings reveal a cholesterol level of 170 mg/dL. The physician prescribes aspirin to prevent ischemic heart disease. This drug prevents ischemic heart disease by which of the following mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inhibiting TXA2 synthesis by platelets:

  • Aspirin, also known as acetylsalicylic acid, prevents ischemic heart disease by inhibiting the synthesis of thromboxane A2 (TXA2) by platelets. TXA2 is a potent platelet aggregator and vasoconstrictor. By irreversibly inhibiting the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX) in platelets, aspirin reduces the production of TXA2, which helps to prevent platelet aggregation and the formation of blood clots in coronary arteries. This mechanism of action makes aspirin an effective antiplatelet medication for reducing the risk of cardiovascular events, including heart attacks and strokes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inhibiting prostacyclin synthesis: Prostacyclin, also known as prostaglandin I2 (PGI2), is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation. In contrast to inhibiting prostacyclin synthesis, aspirin actually inhibits the synthesis of thromboxane A2, which is derived from arachidonic acid by platelets and has proaggregatory effects. The inhibition of prostacyclin synthesis by aspirin is not its primary mechanism of action in preventing ischemic heart disease.

Option C - Inhibiting the release of EDRF: Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF) refers to nitric oxide (NO), which is a potent vasodilator released by the endothelial cells lining blood vessels. While NO plays a crucial role in vascular health and regulation of blood flow, aspirin's mechanism of action in preventing ischemic heart disease is not directly related to inhibiting the release of EDRF.

Option D - Inhibiting the synthesis of endothelins: Endothelins are vasoconstrictor peptides produced by endothelial cells. They play a role in regulating vascular tone and blood pressure. However, aspirin's mechanism of action in preventing ischemic heart disease does not involve inhibiting the synthesis of endothelins.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in his big toe, and his serum uric acid levels were found to be elevated. After acute treatment, the patient was put on a maintenance regimen with a drug which is considered first-line management for chronic gout; What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Xanthine oxidase inhibitor:

This patient after initial treatment of acute gout flare should be treated with Xanthine oxidase inhibitors which are considered first-line in management of chronic gout, to prevent relapses.

  • Gout is a type of arthritis caused by an accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joints, leading to inflammation and pain. 

  • Xanthine oxidase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of purines, which are converted to uric acid. 

  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors block the activity of this enzyme, resulting in reduced uric acid production and lower levels of uric acid in the blood.

  • Allopurinol and febuxostat are two commonly used xanthine oxidase inhibitors in treating gout.

  • These drugs are considered first-line agents for managing gout in chronic gout, because they effectively reduce serum uric acid levels and prevent gout flares.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pyrimidine antimetabolites: Pyrimidine antimetabolites are drugs that interfere with the synthesis of nucleic acids, specifically pyrimidines, and are used in cancer treatment. They have no role in the treatment of gout.

Option B - Inhibitor of neutrophil recruitment: Inhibitors of neutrophil recruitment are drugs that prevent the migration of white blood cells called neutrophils to the site of inflammation. colchicine works by this mechanism of action, but it is not used in maintenance treatment of gout, instead it is used in acute gout flare.

Option C - Uricosuric drug: Uricosuric drugs are a class of medications that increase the excretion of uric acid by the kidneys, resulting in lower serum uric acid levels. They are used in patients with gout who have under-excretion of uric acid as the cause of their hyperuricemia. However, they are not considered first-line agents in gout treatment and are generally used in combination with xanthine oxidase inhibitors or as an alternative in patients who cannot tolerate xanthine oxidase inhibitors.
